question: 主
sourceAnswer:
<read>しゅ</read>|<read>しゅう</read>:: (one's)-master | Lord | the-main-thing/the-majority/the-primary-concern
<read>ぬし</read>:: head-(of-a-household,-etc.)/leader/master | owner/proprietor/proprietress | subject-(of-a-rumour,-etc.)/doer-(of-a-deed) | guardian-spirit-(e.g.-long-resident-beast,-usu.-with-mystical-powers)/long-time-resident-(or-employee,-etc.) | husband | you
<read>あるじ</read>:: head-(of-a-household)/proprietor-(of-a-store)/proprietress/landlord/landlady/master-(of-a-servant) | entertaining-someone-as-one's-guest
userAnswer:
<read>ぬし:</read> head-(household..)/leader/master | owner/proprietor ...
<read>あるじ:</read> head-of/proprietor/landlord/master
<read>しゅ:</read> <tag>christian:</tag>lord/god ....
activeAnswer:
<read>ぬし:</read> head-(household..)/leader/master | owner/proprietor ...
<read>あるじ:</read> head-of/proprietor/landlord/master
<read>しゅ:</read> <tag>christian:</tag>lord/god ....
sourceMnemonic: This has a similar meaning to <ja>主人</ja> (<vocabulary>head of household</vocabulary>). You can remember it also as the meaning you learned with the kanji <ja>主</ja>, which is <vocabulary>master</vocabulary>.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this:

The person who was your <vocabulary>head of household</vocabulary> was very strict. Anytime you did anything that was incorrect or bad, he/she would pull out the <reading>noose</reading> (<ja>ぬし</ja>), but would call it a "noosey" to be cute, since you were just a kid.
